abstract.p: Human tail refers to a congenital cutaneous appendix protruding from the lumbosacral region. It is usually associated with an underlying spina bifida occulta, a form of spinal dysraphism. A contiguous fibrolipoma can sometimes be seen extending from the subcutaneous portion of the tail into the inferior spinal cord, resulting in tethered cord syndrome. Management of such lesions includes complete neurologic examination and magnetic resonance imaging. Early diagnosis and microsurgical intervention can prevent development or progression of severe neurologic defects in later life.

body.p: Human tail is a rare congenital anomaly that when present in a newborn baby causes anxiety and fear in parents. It is frequently associated with complex spinal abnormalities and may affect the long-term neurologic outcome of the child. Its etiology is poorly understood and there remains a debate among clinicians regarding its management. Reports of this uncommon and interesting anomaly have been available since the 19th century and more than a hundred cases of human tail-like appendage have been reported in Western literature. However, not much literature is available on this entity from the Indian subcontinent.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A newborn, male child presented with an elongated tail-like appendage since birth (Figure 1). The baby was born to a primi gravida mother by caesarian section at 38 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2.2 kg. The mother had gestational hypertension, and her blood pressure was controlled by labetalol. There was no history of a similar lesion or any neurologic disease in the family. On examination, there was a 2 cm × 2 cm soft, nonfluctuant appendage found in the sacral region. It was covered with normal skin. No bony or cartilaginous elements could be palpated in the appendage. The neonate did not have any evidence of paraparesis or bladder-bowel retention or incontinence. The anal tone was normal and anal dimple was present. There was no other congenital anomaly. A radiograph of the lumbosacral spine revealed spinal dysraphism in the form of a spina bifida extending from S1 to S5 vertebra. Magnetic resonance images demonstrated a small elevation seen over the sacrococcygeal region in the midline posteriorly. It was connected with the spinal canal via the spina bifida. No meningocele, lipoma, ependymoma, or astrocytomas were noted. There were no other intraspinal abnormalities (Figure 2). The child was managed conservatively and on follow-up at 3 months did not show any neurologic deficit.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The human tail is an ill-defined, rare, protruding midline lesion of the lumbosacrococcygeal region. Although it has been reported since the late 19th century, its etiology is still unclear. There are embryologic and histopathologic theories explaining the etiology of the human tail. Harrison 1 described human tails as remnants of the embryonic appendage. The embryogenesis of the human tail was first noted in the fourth week of gestation, which usually disappears by the end of the eighth week. Based on histopathology, Dao and Netsky 2 classified human tails into 2 subgroups, true tails and pseudotails. A true tail contains adipose, connective tissue, nerves, blood vessels, and striated muscle covered by normal skin. They are not associated with bone, cartilage, or spinal elements. The pseudotail has a superficial resemblance to the true tail but contains other tissues such as lipoma, teratoma, or myelomeningocele. Dubrow et al reported 24 cases of true tails and 10 of pseudotails from 1884 to 1985. 3 Our patient had a true tail. The human tail was first described on plain radiography in 1960, on computed tomography 4 in 1980, and on magnetic resonance imaging study in 1988.

Spinal dysraphism is the most frequently associated anomaly with human tail. It may be a myelomeningocele, meningocele, or spina bifida. Spina bifida is the most frequently associated spinal dysraphism with both true and pseudotail. 2,5 Tavagni et al 6 reviewed 200 cases of occult spinal dysraphism and reported an association with caudal appendages in more than 50% cases. Hoffman et al 7 reviewed 97 cases of tail-like appendages and reported fatty mass in the lumbosacral region as the most common presenting complaint.

True and pseudo tail cannot be differentiated on clinical examination. A normal neurologic examination or a normal plain radiograph of spine, in such cases must be investigated with neuroimaging for spinal dysraphism, because of their frequent association. Magnetic resonance imaging is the investigation of choice for detecting spinal dysraphism if a tail-like appendage is present. It is also essential for any surgical repair later. Human tails are surgically correctable anomalies. Surgery is aimed at untethering (if tethered spinal cord) the spinal cord as the first step, followed by complete excision of the tail to get rid of the cosmetic deformity.

To summarize, human tail is a benign congenital anomaly. It can be associated with an underlying spinal lesion that, if not recognized early, can lead to permanent neurologic disabilities. Early diagnosis and prompt microsurgical treatment is required to avoid any damage or permanent neurologic deficit in such cases. 8 –10
